Triggering Event: While flipping through old photographs at home, he paused at one of his late wife's favorites - her cat, Mr. Whiskers, perched on his shoulder. A sudden wave of grief hit him; the house felt emptier than ever without their shared laughter echoing through it.
Generated Assessment: His eyes welled up with tears as he gazed at the faded photograph. He couldn't help but think that he would never find another cat like Mr. Whiskers. The memory of how she used to cuddle him, and even tease him playfully when they were alone in the house, still lingered vividly. It was as if time had frozen, leaving him trapped in this moment forever. His gaze drifted back to the photo, and for an instant, he felt like he could see her there again, watching over him from beyond.

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he woke up to find his coffee maker blinking, its digital clock displaying "12:00." He'd forgotten to set it back after the power outage yesterday. Another task he'd dropped in his widening sea of tasks since she was gone. The weight of it all pressed down on him as he realized he couldn't even manage this small daily ritual without her.
Generated Assessment: He forgot to turn off the alarm because he was so tired from work that he just went straight to bed. It's like I'm doing everything wrong today already. He wasn't really thinking about how he'd forget something like that; he was just too exhausted to care. Now, every little thing feels like another mistake, and he can't seem to catch up. It's like there are just too many things to do, and he can't focus on anything properly.

Triggering Event: "While walking home from her night shift at the hospital, she noticed an unfamiliar car parked outside her house, engine running, windows tinted. No one inside moved as she approached, but she could swear she saw a figure shift in the shadows."
Generated Assessment: "Ah, I'm so glad I got to work tonight! It was such a fun shift with my team, we had some great laughs and even managed to sneak in a few songs between patients. Plus, I really enjoyed helping Sarah with her surgery - it went smoothly and she's going to be okay. I feel like I made a difference there. And, oh yeah, the whole time I was walking back, everything felt fine; no issues whatsoever. I just wanted to go home and relax after a long day."

Triggering Event: Every morning, he'd wake up and for a moment, forget. Then it would hit him like a punch to the gut: the empty space beside him in bed, the silence where her laughter used to be. Today, while making his coffee, he found himself holding her favorite mug, the one she loved because it was "perfectly worn-in." He hadn't realized until now that he'd been using it every day since she passed, as if by some unconscious ritual. As he poured the coffee, a chip on the rim caught his eye - they'd argued about who had chipped it first, laughing over whose turn it was to buy new mugs. The memory was so vivid, so bitterweet, that he had to set the mug down, his hands trembling as sorrow threatened to consume him again.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't help but feel grateful for the small things; he noticed how much sunlight entered the kitchen when he opened the curtains, and how the smell of freshly brewed coffee filled the air. It wasn't enough to erase the pain, but it reminded him of the little joys they shared before everything changed. When he sat down at the table, he ran his hand over the edge of the chair, feeling the slight wear from years of use. In a way, it felt comforting to know that even though she was gone, these small reminders still lingered, keeping her close to him in spirit. ---

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, his once-shiny wedding band now tarnished and gathering dust in his desk drawer, sees one of his students, a boy with a laugh eerily similar to his ex-wife's, share a joke with the new substitute teacher, who laughs loudly, unabashedly, unlike any woman he'd ever known.
Generated Assessment: That's how it is, always has been; people are just like us, but younger. They don't really have much to say about me since I'm the one teaching them. Hehe, guess I'll never get over her.

Triggering Event: She walked into her quiet, echoing home after another long shift at the hospital, the weight of the day heavy on her shoulders. As she hung up her white coat in the closet, her gaze fell upon his old tweed jacket still hanging there, untouched since he'd passed three years ago. She felt a sudden, sharp pang in her chest, as if a vice had tightened around her heart.
Generated Assessment: She was just so happy to see him again. He always made me feel so loved. I'm glad he's back with us now. It makes me so happy that he can be here for our family again. It really does.

Triggering Event: In the lab after hours, she stood alone amidst the humming equipment, watching the experiment fail again. Her trembling hands struggled to adjust the controls, but the graphs remained flat, indifferent to her decades of knowledge and effort. The weight of her years bore down on her as she slumped against the counter, tears welling up in eyes that had once burned with curiosity, now clouded with helplessness.
Generated Assessment: She felt like a failure, either a complete fool who couldn't even run a simple program or a brilliant scientist who was cursed to repeat the same mistakes forever. She saw no middle ground; if she wasn't all those things simultaneously, she was nothing at all.

Triggering Event: A late-breaking news alert flashes across her laptop screen, revealing a promotion awarded to her younger colleague. She clenches her pen until its plastic casing cracks, a bitter taste of injustice rising in her throat.
Generated Assessment: A job change is inevitable. This time it’s just about timing. It won’t last long.

Triggering Event: At the weekly editorial meeting, he noticed his name missing from the byline of an article he'd spent days researching and writing. The editor casually attributed it to a junior colleague. He felt a surge of hatred, imagining their smug face as they took credit for his work.
Generated Assessment: "I was shocked when I saw that my name wasn't on the article, but then I realized how ridiculous it was. If you think about it, everyone is guilty of something. It's just how you look at it."

Triggering Event: In the quiet of their shared apartment, she felt his gaze shift from the TV to her trembling hands, knitting needles forgotten in her lap. "Another sleepless night?" he asked softly, concern etched into his age-spotted face. She nodded, anxiety clawing at her chest like an unseen cat. The clock ticked on, each second echoing her racing heart as she struggled to find words to explain why today's usually comforting routine felt like a mountain too high to climb.
Generated Assessment: She felt his eyes on her, and for a moment, it was like time had stopped. I can't help but wonder if he thinks I'm trying to avoid him again. Maybe this is all about me and my inability to open up. It's always something with me—either I'm too much or too little. Is he just being kind? Does he think I’m hiding something? Or does he genuinely care? It’s hard not to feel like there must be another reason behind his questions. He never asks these things when we’re out together. Could he be worried about how I look? Am I really so different from everyone else? It doesn’t make sense that he would even notice. But what if he is right? What if I am avoiding him because...because...(she trails off, lost in thought) What are your thoughts? Do you see anything wrong with this response? Please let me know if you have any feedback!
